III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12205 Required staff
Section (8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient number of
Description competent staff to carry out the provisions covered by these rules.
The workload for each staff member may not be more than any of
the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker for
purposes of providing direct services in foster care,
independent living, adoption, or post adoption services or a
combination thereof.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The facility does not have enough case managers to manage the
cases they have and are unable to fulfill the case management
requirements.
Investigation MDHHS Purchase of Service Foster Care supervisor (MDHHS
POS FC supervisor) was interviewed via telephone on
September 3, 2025. She stated she was notified by her Program
Manager Holy Cross had three staff abruptly quit and walk out on
August 12, 2025. She believed the staff included two direct
workers and one supervisor.
She stated she and BSC 1 & 3 Private Agency Foster Care Key
Performance Indicator Analyst were asked to go over to Holy
Cross Muskegon office and assist them. She clarified this
happened 2 days after the workers and supervisor had walked
out. She stated she was there all day and assisted with
reassignments for the agency cases and ensuring correct staff
were assigned to cases. They went through all the cases and
determined upcoming activities they needed to be aware of such
as court hearings or any reports that may be due. At the end of
that day Staff 1 had 22 cases on his load. She stated there
weren’t other options at that time since Staff 2 was new and could
only take 5 cases. Staff 3 had not started new worker training yet
and wasn’t able to take any cases. Over the following week she
followed up with the agency and inquired what was being done to
get some of the cases off Staff 1’s load as it wasn’t possible for
one worker to manage 22 cases. She stated she inquired who
was doing parenting time, attending court and writing the reports.
They were working quickly to transfer cases to other Private
Agency Foster Care (PAFC) agencies to determine any cases that
could be closed and what activities needed to be completed in
order to get those closed.
2

She felt the agency was doing what they could to get cases
transferred but some of it took time because there were activities
that needed to be completed before the other agency would
accept transfer.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed via teleconference
on September 4, 2025. She stated on August 12, 2025, three
staff, one supervisor and two direct workers, abruptly quit and
walked out. As soon as the staff quit, she had a support staff
contact all the foster homes and caregivers to inform them of what
had occurred and make sure they had the on-call phone number
and support staff phone number. The two remaining case workers,
Staff 1 and Staff 2, contacted the parents from the cases to
schedule monthly meetings and let them know they would be
assigned a new worker.
CA stated at that point the agency had one fully trained staff, Staff
1, and a new staff, Staff 2, who was still in new worker training
and could only take 3 cases. CA stated Staff 1 had up to 22 cases
at one point while the agency was actively working on transferring
cases back to DHHS and some to other private agencies in the
area. She stated they needed to wait for the case transfer
meetings and there were a few cases that needed some activities
to be completed before they could be transferred. Most of the
cases were transferred on September 2, 2025. CA stated as of
September 4, 2025, Staff 1 had 15 cases, Staff 2 is further along
in new worker training and is now able to take 5 cases and there
is a newly hired staff, Staff 3, who just started new worker training,
and she has 3 cases.
BSC 1 & 3 Private Agency Foster Care Key Performance
Indicator Analyst (KPI Analyst) was interviewed via telephone
on September 17, 2025. She works with the agency every month
on their KPI’s for the Modified Implementation, Sustainability and
Exit Plan (MISEP). She knew a supervisor and direct worker at the
agency had put in their notice, and their last scheduled day was
August 20, 2025. At that point she was already working with the
agency on a succession plan for how they would address the loss
of staff.
KPI Analyst stated after three staff walked out on August 12,
2025, the agency was left with only one fully trained staff (Staff 1).
Staff 2 was in new worker training and was only able to have 3
cases; however, was within a few days of being able to have 5
cases. KPI Analyst stated she and MDHHS POS FC supervisor
3

dropped everything to formulate a plan to assist the agency to
transfer cases and determine what case activities needed to be
completed. She stated they identified approximately 6 cases that
could have already been closed. They tried to target those and get
those closed. She contacted another PAFC in the area about
taking some cases. Some of the remaining cases had reports that
were due within a week or a court hearing within a week and an
agency willing to accept the transfer needed to have those things
completed before accepting the transfer.
Documents reviewed:
• August 13, 2025, email to DCWL from Chief Administrator.
“I wanted to notify you that we had three of our staff from
our Muskegon office who walked off the job yesterday thus
leaving us short two workers and one supervisor. We are
working through case assignments and case transfers with
MDHHS. I am available for further conversation should you
need to speak about this today.”
• MISACWIS case review for Staff 1 as of October 1, 2025.
Staff 1 was assigned as primary FCW for 10 cases with a
total of 16 youth.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of MISACWIS information, the agency was
aware at least two staff had put in their notice in early August
2025 and did not appear to have a plan for closing or transferring
cases upon their departure. As of October 1, 2025, MISACWIS
case review determined Staff 1 is still out of caseload compliance
despite adequate time to address case activities needed to
transfer or close the cases to reduce the number of cases
assigned.
Conclusion Violation Established
4

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12202 Policy and procedures
Section (1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
Description procedures for the areas of foster care services as provided in R
400.12203 to R 400.12214.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff provided confidential information to a party outside of the
agency.
Investigation Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed via teleconference
on September 4, 2025. She stated former agency Foster Care
worker (former FCW) was one of the staff who quit and walked out
on August 12, 2025. Upon her abruptly quitting, the CEO of the
agency was reviewing email accounts and found an email former
FCW wrote on July 30, 2025, to another PAFC in the area. In the
email she indicates she is working with two homes that wish to be
licensed, and the Holy Cross Muskegon office does not have a
licensing team and would like to refer them. She provided the
other PAFC with names, phone numbers and email addresses for
the two homes. CA clarified that former FCW had already put in
her notice to quit at the time she walked out, and she was going to
work for the other PAFC who she provided the confidential
information to. CA clarified the agency had a licensing worker at
that time and there would be no reason to contact another agency
about licensing one of their homes.
Former agency Foster Care worker (former FCW) was
interviewed via telephone on September 17, 2025. She stated
she was employed at Holy Cross until August 12, 2025. She
stated at the time she left the agency there was a licensing
worker, but she rarely saw the individual and wasn’t clear on the
current situation of the licensing department at Holy Cross. She
stated she worked with a caregiver who had been trying to
become licensed and was frustrated by the lack of communication
from the licensing department at Holy Cross. During the interview
the email former FCW wrote regarding Foster Home 1 & Foster
Home 2 was discussed. She stated Holy Cross licensing was not
following through with assisting Foster Home 2 on becoming
licensed. It was reported to her that no one from licensing had
made contact with the family since approximately January 2025.
She stated she had heard of a new agency in the area that was
licensing homes and thought they might be able to assist the
caregiver. Once she became aware she could not make the
referral she stopped pursuing that.
5

Documents reviewed:
• July 30, 2025, email from former FCW to other area
PAFC. “Good evening, My agency currently does not have
a licensing team in Muskegon so I’m hoping that you are
able to accept these referrals. Please let me know if you
have any further questions! The homes are below: Foster
Home 1 (provides their phone number and email address)
and Foster Home 2 (provides their phone number and
email address).
• Holy Cross Privacy & Security of Participant Records
Policy & Procedure.
Policy Statement: These regulations govern
confidentiality, privacy, and security of the records of
participants, including records related to mental health,
substance use, co-occurring, physical health and child
welfare-related services.
Impermissible Use or Disclosure: The acquisition,
access, use, or disclosure of confidential information, PII, or
PHI in a manner not permitted under HIPAA or other
applicable confidentiality laws that may or may not
compromise the security or privacy of the confidential
information, PII, or PHI.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of documentation, former FCW violated
agency policies and procedures by providing confidential
information regarding two of Holy Cross’ enrolled foster homes to
another PAFC. Former FCW only had access to this information
due to her position at Holy Cross and she was not given
permission to share.
Conclusion Violation Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.

sir_summary.summary: The investigation found Holy Cross Services violated staffing and policy rules after three staff abruptly quit. A remaining worker was assigned up to 22 foster care cases, exceeding the 15-case limit, and a former worker improperly shared confidential foster home information with a competing agency. While the crisis was triggered by staff resignations, the agency is culpable for inadequate succession planning and failing to prevent the unauthorized data disclosure.

sir_violation_level.justification: The substantiated violations include a staffing/supervision failure (caseloads exceeding the rule of 15 per worker, with one worker having 22 cases, indicating a facility-level breakdown and failure to provide sufficient staff) and a policy violation involving the impermissible disclosure of confidential client information to an outside party. These align with the 'Moderate SIRs' categories of 'Environmental or supervision failures' and 'Administrative or Rights-Related Issues' (specifically policy violations raising compliance questions).
